Counterparts

This Deed may be executed in any number of separate counterparts and this has the same effect as if the signatures on those counterparts were on a single copy of this Deed.

Each Party may evidence their execution of this Deed by faxing or by emailing an executed signature page of this Deed in PDF format together with the final version of this Deed in PDF or Word format, which shall constitute an original executed counterpart of this Deed. Each Party adopting this method of execution will, following circulation by fax or by email, provide the original, hard copy executed signature page to the other Party as soon as reasonably practicable.

Clause 35—Counterparts

A counterparts clause is a common boilerplate clause which provides that the parties to an agreement may execute separate copies of it, rather than all parties having to sign the same copy of the agreement. It is common practice to sign an agreement in counterparts, and this mechanism can be particularly useful where there are a large number of parties, or where the parties are located in different regions or countries and will be unable to hold a physical completion meeting.

If an agreement does not contain a counterparts clause, the parties will not be prevented from executing a document in counterpart. However, using a counterparts clause is advisable for certainty, and to prevent any argument that the agreement is not binding because it has not been properly executed.

The counterparts clause commonly consists of:

  • a statement that the document may be executed in counterparts, and

  • a sub-clause dealing with virtual signing (ie circulating the signature pages by email)

The difference between original counterparts and original duplicates should be noted here. If all the parties sign a number of copies of the agreement, each copy is an original duplicate rather than a counterpart, and the counterparts clause will not be applicable.

The Mercury Tax case considered the effectiveness of pre-signed signature pages and virtual signings and closings where signature pages are exchanged by email (Re Mercury Tax [2008] All ER (D) 129 (Nov)). Following this case, the Law Society issued guidance on good practice for virtual signings (Law Society Guidance: Execution of documents by virtual means).

The Law Society guidance sets out three options for the virtual signing of an agreement or deed. Agreements that are to be executed as a deed should follow option 1 of the guidance.

The Law Society recommends that all parties’ lawyers agree to the proposed arrangements for the virtual signing/closing well in advance of execution. For this reason, it has become common practice to include specific drafting on virtual signings in the counterparts clause (see Clause 35.2).

Option 1 gives guidance on circulating the entire document and the signed signature page by email. This method is suitable for both deeds and simple contracts. The detailed requirements for option 1 are as follows:

  • execution copies of the documents are emailed as PDF or Word attachments to all parties that will be absent and/or their lawyers (as agreed); the signature page may be emailed as a separate PDF or Word document, for convenience

  • each absent signatory then prints and signs the signature page only (there is no need to print off the full document)

  • each absent party then returns a single email to their lawyer or to the lawyers coordinating signing/closing as agreed and attaches both the final version of the PDF or Word agreement and a PDF copy of the signed signature page, and

  • at or shortly after signing/closing, the parties may wish to evidence the execution by one of the law firms circulating a final version of the document together with copies of executed signature pages

The Law Society guidance confirms that, for option 1, the PDF or Word final version of the document and the PDF of the signed signature page will constitute an original signed document and each counterpart taken together will equate to the same physical document.

Option 2 allows the parties to circulate the signature page by email, without a copy of the final agreement (so is slightly less burdensome than option 1). This method is only suitable for simple contracts (not deeds).

Option 3 allows the parties to sign and circulate the signature pages in advance of finalising a document. This method is only suitable for simple contracts (not deeds).

For further information on signing see Practice Note: Virtual execution of documents.

Clause 35.2

It has become common practice to have a sub-clause within the counterparts clause which deals with virtual signing (ie the circulation of signature pages by email or fax) following the Mercury Tax case and subsequent Law Society guidance. The entire sub-clause can be deleted if the parties are not intending to circulate signature pages electronically.

  • each absent party then returns a single email to their lawyer or to the lawyers coordinating signing/closing as agreed and attaches both the final version of the PDF or Word agreement and a PDF copy of the signed signature page, and

  • at or shortly after signing/closing, the parties may wish to evidence the execution by one of the law firms circulating a final version of the document together with copies of executed signature pages

The Law Society guidance confirms that, for option 1, the PDF or Word final version of the document and the PDF of the signed signature page will constitute an original signed document and each counterpart taken together will equate to the same physical document.

Option 2 allows the parties to circulate the signature page by email, without a copy of the final agreement (so is slightly less burdensome than option 1). This method is only suitable for simple contracts (not deeds). The detailed requirements for option 2 are as follows:

  • the final execution copies of the documents must be emailed as a PDF or Word attachement to all absent parties and/or their lawyers, as agreed; the signature page may be emailed as a separate PDF or Word document, for convenience

  • each absent signatory then prints and signs the signature page only (there is no need to print off the full document)

  • each absent party then emails its signature page as a PDF attachment to their lawyer or to the lawyers coordinating signing/closing as agreed, giving authority to attach it to the final approved version of the document, and

  • at or shortly after signing/closing, the parties may wish to evidence the execution by one of the law firms circulating a final version of the document together with copies of executed signature pages

The Law Society guidance confirms that for option 2, the print-off of the final execution version of the document together with the attached signed signature pages will constitute an original signed document.

Option 3 allows the parties to sign and circulate the signature pages in advance of finalising a document. This method is only suitable for simple contracts (not deeds). The detailed requirements for option 3 are:

  • enough time should be allowed to coordinate the circulation of the signature pages prior to signing/closing and each signature page should clearly identify the document to which it relates

  • the signature page should be executed by each of the signatories and returned to their lawyers or the law firm coordinating the signing/closing, as agreed, by email (as a PDF attachment) or by courier, to be held to the order of the signatory or their lawyers, until authority is given for it to be attached to the document to be signed, and

  • when each document has been finalised, the law firm coordinating the signing/closing should email the final version of the document to each absent party and/or their lawyers and obtain confirmation from them or their lawyers that they have agreed the final version of the document, and authorising the relevant law firm to attach the pre-signed signature page to the final version and to date and release the document

The guidance confirms that the final approved version of the agreement, with the pre-signed signature pages that have been attached with the prior approval of the parties or their lawyers, will constitute an original signed document. For further information on signing see Practice Note: Virtual execution of documents.

Agreements that are executed as simple contracts (such as the Facility Agreement) can use any of the three options outlined in the Law Society guidance. The wording set out in the first set of square brackets in sub-clause xref follows option 1. The alternative wording in the second set of square brackets is suitable if the parties are following option 2 or 3.

The entire sub-clause can be deleted if the parties are not intending to circulate signature pages electronically.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem53660225-a9fd-45f8-a7e6-0c6b2158df4e"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Compliance with law</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Each <lnb-prec:term>party</lnb-prec:term> shall comply and shall (at its own expense unless expressly agreed otherwise) ensure that in the performance of its duties under this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term>, its employees, agents and representatives will comply with all applicable laws and regulations, provided that neither <lnb-prec:term>party</lnb-prec:term> shall be liable for any breach of this clause <lnb-prec:xref title="ukContentItem53660225-a9fd-45f8-a7e6-0c6b2158df4e" style="color:red; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">xref</lnb-prec:xref> to the extent that such breach is directly caused or contributed to by any breach of this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> by the other <lnb-prec:term>party</lnb-prec:term> (or its employees, agents and representatives).</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem3dba997b-120c-4340-bf2d-70bc8bebe557"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem53660225-a9fd-45f8-a7e6-0c6b2158df4e" type="clause"/>—Compliance with law</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This clause places a contractual obligation on both parties to comply with applicable laws, regulations and guidelines. For alternative forms of wording and drafting note, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_1465005"><lnci:content>Compliance with law and regulation clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Compliance with law

Each party shall comply and shall (at its own expense unless expressly agreed otherwise) ensure that in the performance of its duties under this Agreement, its employees, agents and representatives will comply with all applicable laws and regulations, provided that neither party shall be liable for any breach of this clause xref to the extent that such breach is directly caused or contributed to by any breach of this Agreement by the other party (or its employees, agents and representatives).

Clause —Compliance with law

This clause places a contractual obligation on both parties to comply with applicable laws, regulations and guidelines. For alternative forms of wording and drafting note, see Precedent: Compliance with law and regulation clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem7ffe2a15-0caa-44f5-a5de-4ccfd45d43de"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Governing law</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> and any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, it, its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims) shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of England and Wales.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem4321f6ef-2ddf-491d-a9ce-883987f057e7"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem7ffe2a15-0caa-44f5-a5de-4ccfd45d43de" type="clause"/>—Governing law</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This governing law clause specifies the substantive law to be applied in interpretation of the agreement and any dispute in relation to it. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of governing law clauses, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_181565"><lnci:content>Governing law clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Governing law

This Agreement and any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, it, its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims) shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of England and Wales.

Clause —Governing law

This governing law clause specifies the substantive law to be applied in interpretation of the agreement and any dispute in relation to it. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of governing law clauses, see Precedent: Governing law clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentIteme2ecbab4-e486-4b68-b19a-74013805d2d5"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Jurisdiction</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>The <lnb-prec:term>parties</lnb-prec:term> irrevocably agree that the courts of England and Wales shall have <lnb-prec:field alt-key="2345">exclusive</lnb-prec:field><lnb-prec:field alt-key="2345">non-exclusive</lnb-prec:field> jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, this <lnb-prec:term>Agreement</lnb-prec:term>, its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims).</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem5fceb874-fdf2-461b-82b6-dccbb645e360"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentIteme2ecbab4-e486-4b68-b19a-74013805d2d5" type="clause"/>—Jurisdiction</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This jurisdiction clause specifies the courts that are to have jurisdiction to hear disputes that arise in relation to the agreement. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of jurisdiction clauses, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_181753"><lnci:content>Jurisdiction clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Jurisdiction

The parties irrevocably agree that the courts of England and Wales shall have exclusivenon-exclusive jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, this Agreement, its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims).

Clause —Jurisdiction

This jurisdiction clause specifies the courts that are to have jurisdiction to hear disputes that arise in relation to the agreement. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of jurisdiction clauses, see Precedent: Jurisdiction clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItema764281a-9944-49b1-9286-74816e21d966"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Announcements</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>No announcement or other public disclosure concerning this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> or any of the matters contained in it shall be made by, or on behalf of, a party without the prior written consent of the other party (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed), except as required by law, any court, any governmental, regulatory or supervisory authority (including any recognised investment exchange) or any other authority of competent jurisdiction.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentIteme7458132-b568-40f1-8980-6ce5a3bdbe30"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItema764281a-9944-49b1-9286-74816e21d966" type="clause"/>—Announcements</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This announcements clause governs the disclosure of information relating to the existence and subject matter of the agreement. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of announcement provisions, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_177745"><lnci:content>Announcements clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Announcements

No announcement or other public disclosure concerning this Agreement or any of the matters contained in it shall be made by, or on behalf of, a party without the prior written consent of the other party (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed), except as required by law, any court, any governmental, regulatory or supervisory authority (including any recognised investment exchange) or any other authority of competent jurisdiction.

Clause —Announcements

This announcements clause governs the disclosure of information relating to the existence and subject matter of the agreement. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of announcement provisions, see Precedent: Announcements clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem938717f9-b71b-450e-ba97-5709a96f8c92"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Waiver</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>No failure, delay or omission by either party in exercising any right, power or remedy provided by law or under this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> shall operate as a waiver of that right, power or remedy, nor shall it preclude or restrict any future exercise of that or any other right or remedy. No single or partial exercise of any right, power or remedy provided by law or under this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> shall prevent any future exercise of it or the exercise of any other right, power or remedy.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItemd845f169-5bce-4479-9dfb-0ce06fbb4107"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem938717f9-b71b-450e-ba97-5709a96f8c92" type="clause"/>—Waiver</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This waiver clause seeks to prevent inadvertent waivers of legal rights. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of waiver clauses, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_180404"><lnci:content>Waiver clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Waiver

No failure, delay or omission by either party in exercising any right, power or remedy provided by law or under this Agreement shall operate as a waiver of that right, power or remedy, nor shall it preclude or restrict any future exercise of that or any other right or remedy. No single or partial exercise of any right, power or remedy provided by law or under this Agreement shall prevent any future exercise of it or the exercise of any other right, power or remedy.

Clause —Waiver

This waiver clause seeks to prevent inadvertent waivers of legal rights. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of waiver clauses, see Precedent: Waiver clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem64508a02-66e8-4fe4-aaa7-732c516bd2bc"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Force majeure</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Neither party shall have any liability under or be deemed to be in breach of this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> for any delays or failures in performance of this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> which result from any event beyond the reasonable control of that party. The party affected by such an event shall promptly notify the other party in writing when such an event causes a delay or failure in performance and when it ceases to do so. If such an event continues for a continuous period of more than <lnb-prec:field type="number">three</lnb-prec:field> months, <lnb-prec:field alt-key="alt-D15E3620001">the party not affected</lnb-prec:field><lnb-prec:field alt-key="alt-D15E3620001">either party</lnb-prec:field> may terminate this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> by written notice to the other party.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem29ab3120-63f4-4090-9fca-c2caff8d49f5"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem64508a02-66e8-4fe4-aaa7-732c516bd2bc" type="clause"/>—Force majeure</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This force majeure clause exempts the parties from liability, and gives them the right to terminate the agreement, if events occur that are beyond their reasonable control. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of force majeure provisions, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_122582"><lnci:content>Force majeure clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Force majeure

Neither party shall have any liability under or be deemed to be in breach of this Agreement for any delays or failures in performance of this Agreement which result from any event beyond the reasonable control of that party. The party affected by such an event shall promptly notify the other party in writing when such an event causes a delay or failure in performance and when it ceases to do so. If such an event continues for a continuous period of more than three months, the party not affectedeither party may terminate this Agreement by written notice to the other party.

Clause —Force majeure

This force majeure clause exempts the parties from liability, and gives them the right to terminate the agreement, if events occur that are beyond their reasonable control. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of force majeure provisions, see Precedent: Force majeure clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem8dabc94d-ac15-4f02-b7c0-d40242fcca95"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Assignment</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:clause-group number-type="number"><lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem59e96927-0e9a-43b9-8263-676fc6be976c"><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>No party may assign, subcontract or encumber any right or obligation under this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term>, in whole or in part, without the other’s prior written consent <lnb-prec:field opt-key="opt-A3E879F9">(such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed)</lnb-prec:field>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:clause><lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem09dfb0d4-9b33-4035-8633-a3e51a057554"><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Notwithstanding clause <lnb-prec:xref title="ukContentItem59e96927-0e9a-43b9-8263-676fc6be976c" style="color:red; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">xref</lnb-prec:xref>, a party may perform any of its obligations and exercise any of its rights granted under this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> through any <lnb-prec:term>Affiliate</lnb-prec:term>, provided that it gives the other party prior written notice including the identity of the relevant <lnb-prec:term>Affiliate</lnb-prec:term>. Each party acknowledges and agrees that any act or omission of its <lnb-prec:term>Affiliate</lnb-prec:term> in relation to that party’s rights or obligations under this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> shall be deemed to be an act or omission of that party itself.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:clause></lnb-prec:clause-group><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentIteme0b3ce23-2bd3-455c-903a-f1b96ceb4e77"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem8dabc94d-ac15-4f02-b7c0-d40242fcca95" type="clause"/>—Assignment</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This assignment clause governs the extent to which a party’s rights and obligations under an agreement may be transferred to a third party. For examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of assignment provisions, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_179778"><lnci:content>Assignment clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>. A definition of Affiliate should be added to the definitions section of the agreement. See Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_188755"><lnci:content>Affiliate definition</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Assignment

No party may assign, subcontract or encumber any right or obligation under this Agreement, in whole or in part, without the other’s prior written consent (such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed).

Notwithstanding clause xref, a party may perform any of its obligations and exercise any of its rights granted under this Agreement through any Affiliate, provided that it gives the other party prior written notice including the identity of the relevant Affiliate. Each party acknowledges and agrees that any act or omission of its Affiliate in relation to that party’s rights or obligations under this Agreement shall be deemed to be an act or omission of that party itself.

Clause —Assignment

This assignment clause governs the extent to which a party’s rights and obligations under an agreement may be transferred to a third party. For examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of assignment provisions, see Precedent: Assignment clause. A definition of Affiliate should be added to the definitions section of the agreement. See Precedent: Affiliate definition.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem0c4ee201-76ae-4075-9ccb-7ed84bffedb3"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Dispute resolution</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:clause-group number-type="number"><lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem287676d9-64ed-4be7-9b51-850e2b367709"><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>If any dispute arises between the parties out of or in connection with this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term>, the matter shall be referred to senior representatives of each party who shall use their reasonable endeavours to resolve it.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:clause><lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItemd67baec7-3fca-401d-aded-11516d5a471d"><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>If the dispute is not resolved within <lnb-prec:field type="text">14 days</lnb-prec:field> of the referral being made under clause <lnb-prec:xref title="ukContentItem287676d9-64ed-4be7-9b51-850e2b367709" style="color:red; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">xref</lnb-prec:xref>, the parties <lnb-prec:field alt-key="alt-AE11E615">shall</lnb-prec:field><lnb-prec:field alt-key="alt-AE11E615"> may</lnb-prec:field> resolve the matter through mediation in accordance with the London Court of International Arbitration Mediation Rules.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:clause><lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem207d5243-cdd6-4a85-9a2c-f370d05f0d79"><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:field alt-key="alt-AE121D41">Either party may issue formal legal proceedings or commence arbitration at any time whether or not the steps referred to in clauses <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem287676d9-64ed-4be7-9b51-850e2b367709" type="clause"/> and <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItemd67baec7-3fca-401d-aded-11516d5a471d" type="clause"/> have been completed.</lnb-prec:field><lnb-prec:field alt-key="alt-AE121D41"> Until the parties have completed the steps referred to in clauses <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem287676d9-64ed-4be7-9b51-850e2b367709" type="clause"/> and <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItemd67baec7-3fca-401d-aded-11516d5a471d" type="clause"/>, and have failed to resolve the dispute, neither party shall commence formal legal proceedings or arbitration except that either party may at any time seek urgent interim relief.</lnb-prec:field></lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:clause></lnb-prec:clause-group><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItemc7529c4a-efda-4fa4-9813-59759d53f266"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem0c4ee201-76ae-4075-9ccb-7ed84bffedb3" type="clause"/>—Dispute resolution</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This dispute resolution clause requires the parties to use reasonable endeavours to resolve disputes internally before referring the matter to mediation. For alternative forms of wording and detailed drafting notes, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_1462243"><lnci:content>Dispute resolution clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Dispute resolution

If any dispute arises between the parties out of or in connection with this Agreement, the matter shall be referred to senior representatives of each party who shall use their reasonable endeavours to resolve it.

If the dispute is not resolved within 14 days of the referral being made under clause xref, the parties shall may resolve the matter through mediation in accordance with the London Court of International Arbitration Mediation Rules.

Either party may issue formal legal proceedings or commence arbitration at any time whether or not the steps referred to in clauses and have been completed. Until the parties have completed the steps referred to in clauses and , and have failed to resolve the dispute, neither party shall commence formal legal proceedings or arbitration except that either party may at any time seek urgent interim relief.

Clause —Dispute resolution

This dispute resolution clause requires the parties to use reasonable endeavours to resolve disputes internally before referring the matter to mediation. For alternative forms of wording and detailed drafting notes, see Precedent: Dispute resolution clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem28512f0b-78f5-494a-b0dd-bc874e473a3b"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Set off</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:field alt-connector="or" alt-key="alt-D15E5020001">Except as expressly set out in this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term>, each</lnb-prec:field><lnb-prec:field alt-connector="or" alt-key="alt-D15E5020001">Each</lnb-prec:field> party shall pay all sums that it owes to the other party under this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> without any set-off, counterclaim, deduction or withholding of any kind, save as may be required by law.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem73d7a6e5-543c-47a8-b9c4-9935df69a21a"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem28512f0b-78f5-494a-b0dd-bc874e473a3b" type="clause"/>—Set off</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This set off clause prohibits the parties from deducting sums owed to them from amounts they owe under the agreement. For alternative wording (including clauses that permit set off in certain circumstances) and analysis of the operation of set off clauses, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_224362"><lnci:content>Set-off clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Set off

Except as expressly set out in this Agreement, eachEach party shall pay all sums that it owes to the other party under this Agreement without any set-off, counterclaim, deduction or withholding of any kind, save as may be required by law.

Clause —Set off

This set off clause prohibits the parties from deducting sums owed to them from amounts they owe under the agreement. For alternative wording (including clauses that permit set off in certain circumstances) and analysis of the operation of set off clauses, see Precedent: Set-off clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItemaba8c02e-6c0b-4151-923b-05b297a85a11"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>No partnership or agency</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Nothing in this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> constitutes, or shall be deemed to constitute, a partnership between the parties nor make any party the agent of another party.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItemf62d7755-9e8c-430a-a06e-d7f12aacfde9"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItemaba8c02e-6c0b-4151-923b-05b297a85a11" type="clause"/>—No partnership or agency</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This no partnership or agency clause seeks to avoid an agreement inadvertently creating an unintended legal relationship between the parties, such as one of partnership or agency. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of no partnership or agency clauses, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_216648"><lnci:content>No partnership or agency</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
No partnership or agency

Nothing in this Agreement constitutes, or shall be deemed to constitute, a partnership between the parties nor make any party the agent of another party.

Clause —No partnership or agency

This no partnership or agency clause seeks to avoid an agreement inadvertently creating an unintended legal relationship between the parties, such as one of partnership or agency. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of no partnership or agency clauses, see Precedent: No partnership or agency.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItemfa80d880-d84c-4e3d-ace8-ee0792ea54eb"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Severance</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>If any provision of this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> (or part of any provision) is or becomes illegal, invalid or unenforceable, the legality, validity and enforceability of any other provision of this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> shall not be affected.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem4659e787-1724-4de5-9ebf-98870014e54a"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItemfa80d880-d84c-4e3d-ace8-ee0792ea54eb" type="clause"/>—Severance</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This severance clause seeks to ensure that the agreement survives and continues to be valid in the event that any provision (or any part of a provision) is found to be illegal, invalid or unenforceable. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of severance clauses, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_177488"><lnci:content>Severance clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Severance

If any provision of this Agreement (or part of any provision) is or becomes illegal, invalid or unenforceable, the legality, validity and enforceability of any other provision of this Agreement shall not be affected.

Clause —Severance

This severance clause seeks to ensure that the agreement survives and continues to be valid in the event that any provision (or any part of a provision) is found to be illegal, invalid or unenforceable. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of severance clauses, see Precedent: Severance clause.

html:
Notices

Notices under this Agreement shall be in writing and sent to a party's registered officeaddress as set out on the first page of this Agreement (or to the fax number or email address set out below). Notices may be given, and shall be deemed received:

by first-class post: two Business Days after posting;

by airmail: seven Business Days after posting;

by hand: on delivery;

by fax to number in the case of party and number in the case of party: on receipt of a successful transmission report; and

by email to address in the case of party and address in the case of party: on receipt of a deliveryread receipt email.

This clause does not apply to notices given in legal proceedings or arbitration.

A notice given under this Agreement is not validly served if sent by email.

Clause —Notices

This notices clause describes how the parties must serve notices under the agreement and when the notices are deemed to be received. For alternative clauses and detailed drafting notes, see Precedent: Notices clause.

html:
In this Agreement:

a reference to this Agreement includes its schedules, appendices and annexes (if any);

a reference to a ‘party’ includes that party’s personal representatives, successors and permitted assigns;

a reference to a ‘person’ includes a natural person, corporate or unincorporated body (in each case whether or not having separate legal personality) and that person’s personal representatives, successors and permitted assigns;

a reference to a gender includes each other gender;

words in the singular include the plural and vice versa;

any words that follow 'include', 'includes', 'including', ‘in particular’ or any similar words and expressions shall be construed as illustrative only and shall not limit the sense of any word, phrase, term, definition or description preceding those words;

the table of contents, background section and any clause, schedule or other headings in this Agreement are included for convenience only and shall have no effect on the interpretation of this Agreement; and

a reference to legislation is a reference to that legislation as in force as at the date of this Agreementamended, extended, re-enacted or consolidated from time to time except to the extent that any such amendment, extension or re-enactment would increase or alter the liability of a party under this Agreement.

Clause —Interpretation

This interpretation clause applies selected principles of interpretation to the agreement. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of interpretation provisions, see Precedent: Definitions and interpretation clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItembde5c411-c98f-4348-a593-05ab24ca194c"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Variation</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>No variation of this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> shall be valid or effective unless it is in writing, refers to this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> and is duly signed or executed by, or on behalf of, each party.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItema2f416fa-e0da-46bd-8262-41406ab4225b"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItembde5c411-c98f-4348-a593-05ab24ca194c" type="clause"/>—Variation</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This variation clause aims to exclude any oral variations to the agreement and to ensure that any variation agreed by the parties is clearly documented and authorised. For examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of variation provisions, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_177485"><lnci:content>Variation clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Variation

No variation of this Agreement shall be valid or effective unless it is in writing, refers to this Agreement and is duly signed or executed by, or on behalf of, each party.

Clause —Variation

This variation clause aims to exclude any oral variations to the agreement and to ensure that any variation agreed by the parties is clearly documented and authorised. For examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of variation provisions, see Precedent: Variation clause.

Further assurance

Each party shall at the request of the other, and at the cost of the requesting party, do all acts and execute all documents which are necessary to give full effect to this Agreement.

Clause —Further assurance

This further assurance clause obliges a party, at the request of the other, to carry out all actions and execute all documents required to give full effect to the agreement. For drafting notes, see Precedent: Further assurance clause.

Entire agreement

Each party acknowledges that it has not entered into this Agreement or any documents entered into pursuant to itinsert name(s) of specific document(s) in reliance on, and shall have no remedies in respect of, any representation or warranty that is not expressly set out in this Agreement or any documents entered into pursuant to itinsert name(s) of specified document(s), except in the case of fraudulent misrepresentation. No party shall have any claim for innocent or negligent misrepresentation on the basis of any statement in this Agreement.

Clause —Entire agreement

This entire agreement clause aims to exclude other documents or statements from forming part of the contract. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of entire agreement provisions, see Precedent: Entire agreement clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem9f658ca2-4e38-48e7-89e0-7c4015274d82"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Third party rights</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>No one other than a party to this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term><lnb-prec:field opt-key="opt-N65821">, their successors and permitted assignees</lnb-prec:field> shall have any right to enforce any of its provisions.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem8881abd3-fadb-45b5-bc63-55b35223f2c9"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem9f658ca2-4e38-48e7-89e0-7c4015274d82" type="clause"/>—Third party rights</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This rights of third parties clause governs the enforceability by third parties of rights arising under the agreement. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of third party rights clauses, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OKF_177484"><lnci:content>Rights of third parties clause</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:clause>
html:
Third party rights

No one other than a party to this Agreement, their successors and permitted assignees shall have any right to enforce any of its provisions.

Clause —Third party rights

This rights of third parties clause governs the enforceability by third parties of rights arising under the agreement. For a long form clause, examples of alternative wording and analysis of the operation of third party rights clauses, see Precedent: Rights of third parties clause.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem66331d38-037d-4dde-b923-d862eec970bb" opt-key="opt-N72516"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:party>Guarantor</lnb-prec:party></lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem1494500282-101398358"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem66331d38-037d-4dde-b923-d862eec970bb" type="clause"/>—Guarantor</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This guarantee clause is suitable for use where the Seller requires some security that the Buyer will observe its obligations in the contract. The guarantee clause provides that if the Buyer defaults the guarantor will perform those obligations (and this will include the obligation to pay the purchase price to the Seller). The guarantor also indemnifies the Seller against any losses or liability incurred because of the Buyer’s default. Delete if no guarantor is being provided.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Where the agreed heads of terms incorporate a rental guarantee by the Seller for void occupational rents post-Completion, see Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OL6_245546"><lnci:content>Rental guarantee schedule</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>In consideration of the Guarantor

Clause —Guarantor

This guarantee clause is suitable for use where the Seller requires some security that the Buyer will observe its obligations in the contract. The guarantee clause provides that if the Buyer defaults the guarantor will perform those obligations (and this will include the obligation to pay the purchase price to the Seller). The guarantor also indemnifies the Seller against any losses or liability incurred because of the Buyer’s default. Delete if no guarantor is being provided.

Where the agreed heads of terms incorporate a rental guarantee by the Seller for void occupational rents post-Completion, see Precedent: Rental guarantee schedule.

In consideration of the Seller entering into this Agreement at the Guarantor'’s request the Guarantor agrees with the Seller as a primary obligation as follows:

the Buyer must perform and observe all of the Buyer’s obligations in this Agreement;

if the Buyer defaults in performing its obligations in this Agreement the Guarantor will perform them;

the Guarantor will indemnify the Seller against all claims, demands, damages, losses, liability, costs, fees and expenses sustained by the Seller by reason of, or arising in any way directly or indirectly out of, the Buyer's default in performing its obligations in this Agreement;

if this Agreement has been disclaimed following the insolvency of the Buyer the Seller may serve notice in writing on the Guarantor (the ‘Guarantor Notice’) requiring the Guarantor to complete the purchase of the Property in accordance with this Agreement with the following modifications:

all obligations of the Buyer shall be deemed to have been entered into by the Guarantor as though it were named as Buyer in place of the party defined as the Buyer in this Agreement;

if a notice to complete served by the Seller on the Buyer has expired at the date of service of the Guarantor Notice the Completion Date shall be 5 working days after the date of service of the Guarantor Notice;

the Guarantor is to pay:

Interest on the balance of the Price from the contractual Completion Date until Completion inclusive of both days; and

all money expended by the Seller in consequence of the Buyer's default from the date of expenditure until Completion inclusive of both days;

for the avoidance of doubt no further deposit shall be payable by the Guarantor;

Clause —Disclaimer

This gives the Seller the ability to require the Guarantor to take a transfer of the Property in the event that the contract is disclaimed. See Practice Note: The process of disclaimer by a liquidator or trustee in bankruptcy under sections 178 or 315 of the Insolvency Act 1986.

the liability of the Guarantor shall not be affected reduced or extinguished by:

any time or indulgence granted by the Seller to the Buyer;

any neglect or forbearance of the Seller in enforcing its rights under this Agreement;

any variation of this Agreement agreed between the Seller and the Buyer; or

the fact that any other person or entity comprising the Guarantor or intended to comprise the Guarantor has not executed this Agreement or is not bound by the guarantee in clause xref;

Clause —Signatories

Harvey v Dunbar Assets plc [2013] All ER (D) 400 (Jul)In Harvey the court decided a bank guarantee was subject to a condition that it would be signed by all the other intended guarantors named in the deed, and, so, liability as a ‘Guarantor’ was only imposed on an individual signatory to the document in circumstances where all the named individuals did indeed sign the guarantee. This meant the individual being sued was never on the hook as guarantor because one of the intended guarantors had not signed the document (his signature had been forged). The guarantee was a single composite document, which sought to impose joint and several liability on four individuals together defined as ‘the Guarantor’ and envisaged it would be signed by all four individuals. There was nothing in the wording excluding the result that all intended guarantors had to sign for an individual guarantor to be liable. It is assumed that the contract into which this clause is inserted provides for joint and several liability where obligations are owed by more than one party. This sub-clause is an attempt to avoid the problem in Harvey as whilst the case relates to a bank guarantee it could, of course, be of wider application in the context of guarantees. It has not been tested in court.

anything else by which apart from clause xref the Guarantor would be released other than a release under seal.

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem247936ef-500d-40a2-8f77-744bae30bded" opt-key="opt-N70726"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Capital allowances</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:clause-group number-type="number"><lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItemebd1b413-4c26-4c47-876d-9d7166eb7d8d"><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>In clause <lnb-prec:xref title="ukContentItem247936ef-500d-40a2-8f77-744bae30bded" style="color:red; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">xref</lnb-prec:xref> the following definitions apply:</lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItema8c561ba-3721-4e44-b601-b05c3c8c5a73"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem247936ef-500d-40a2-8f77-744bae30bded" type="clause"/>—Capital allowances</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>It is important on any sale of property to consider the position in relation to capital allowances. In order to qualify for plant and machinery allowances, expenditure must be:</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:list number-type="disc"><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>capital</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>on plant and machinery, and</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>wholly or partly for the purposes of a qualifying activity</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem></lnb-prec:list><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>In addition, the person incurring the expenditure must own the plant and machinery as a result of that expenditure. See: <lnci:cite normcite="0OLU_123942"><lnci:content>Capital allowances—overview</lnci:content></lnci:cite> for further information on the qualification criteria.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Properties often have substantial plant and machinery. This may be:</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:list number-type="disc"><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>fixtures, and/or</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>integral features</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem></lnb-prec:list><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>For information on the practicalities of capital allowance-related warranties and pre-contract enquiries on a property transfer, see Practice Note: <lnci:cite normcite="0OLV_185796"><lnci:content>Plant and machinery allowances on property acquisitions and disposals (including pre-contract enquiries)</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>The drafting in this clause is for use where the Seller has claimed allowances and the parties will enter into a section 198 election on Completion. For alternative drafting clauses where the Seller:</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:list number-type="disc"><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>has claimed allowances and the parties will apply to the First-tier Tax Tribunal for a just and reasonable allocation of allowances; or</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>has claimed allowances but the information is not available on completion to enable a section 198 election to be entered into at completion; or</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>has not claimed capital allowances, and was not entitled to do so; or</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:listitem><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>was entitled to claim capital allowances but has not done so</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:listitem></lnb-prec:list><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>see the drafting alternatives and notes in Precedent: <lnci:cite normcite="0OL9_255172"><lnci:content>Capital allowances clauses—property sale contract</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>The purpose of a section 198 election is to determine, for capital allowances purposes, the amount of the price for the Property that should be attributed to fixtures on which the Seller has claimed allowances.</lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:text>Depending on the circumstances, it may be necessary to use more than one variation of the capital gains clauses in this Precedent and also in <lnci:cite normcite="0OL9_255172"><lnci:content>Capital allowances clauses—property sale contract</lnci:content></lnci:cite>. For example, the Property may contain fixtures on which the Seller has claimed allowances, but also fixtures on which the Seller was not entitled to claim allowances, such as cold water or electrical systems acquired before April 2008. In this situation it may be appropriate to use both the drafting in this contract as well as option 4 in <lnci:cite normcite="0OL9_255172"><lnci:content>Capital allowances clauses—property sale contract</lnci:content></lnci:cite>, with modifications to make clear which clause applies to which category of fixture.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>For more information see Practice Notes: <lnci:cite normcite="0OLV_185795"><lnci:content>Plant and machinery allowances—fixtures</lnci:content></lnci:cite> and <lnci:cite normcite="0OLV_185798"><lnci:content>Section 198 and 199 elections on transactions involving real estate property</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:definition><lnb-prec:term>CAA 2001</lnb-prec:term><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Capital Allowances Act 2001;</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:definition><lnb-prec:definition><lnb-prec:term>Election</lnb-prec:term><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>an election in respect of the <lnb-prec:term>Fixtures</lnb-prec:term> under section 198 of <lnb-prec:term>CAA 2001</lnb-prec:term> in the form annexed to this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term> as <lnb-prec:xref title="ukContentItem1529398155-94474267" style="color:red; text-decoration: underline; font-weight: bold;">xref</lnb-prec:xref>;</lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem7ffa5e9f-e1cc-4d3e-a8e7-2a787fd78282"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItemebd1b413-4c26-4c47-876d-9d7166eb7d8d" type="clause"/>—Election</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>For details of elections in real estate transactions, see Practice Note: <lnci:cite normcite="0OLV_185798"><lnci:content>Section 198 and 199 elections on transactions involving real estate property</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:definition><lnb-prec:definition><lnb-prec:term>Fixtures</lnb-prec:term><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>all plant and machinery which is installed or otherwise fixed in or to the <lnb-prec:term>Property</lnb-prec:term> so as to become (in law) part of the <lnb-prec:term>Property</lnb-prec:term>;</lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem047859c8-e9af-4c86-a104-979d3ffe03cc"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItemebd1b413-4c26-4c47-876d-9d7166eb7d8d" type="clause"/>—Fixtures</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>Fixtures are plant or machinery that is installed or fixed so that they become, in law, part of a building or land. Examples include boilers, alarm systems and fitted kitchen units. There are special rules to determine whether a taxpayer is eligible to claim allowances for expenditure on a fixture. In order to claim allowances, the taxpayer must have an interest in the land or building of which the fixture is part. Further rules determine who may claim allowances where more than one person might have a claim, for instance where a person constructs a building, installs fixtures, then leases the building to another person for a capital sum that includes a payment for those fixtures. For new fixtures, the capital allowances claim is based on the actual expenditure. For more information see Practice Note: <lnci:cite normcite="0OLV_185795"><lnci:content>Plant and machinery allowances—fixtures</lnci:content></lnci:cite>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:inclusion></lnb-prec:block></lnb-prec:definition><lnb-prec:definition><lnb-prec:term>Integral Features</lnb-prec:term><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>those <lnb-prec:term>Fixtures</lnb-prec:term> that are integral features for the purposes of section 33(A) of <lnb-prec:term>CAA 2001</lnb-prec:term>;</lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem4e35b866-138c-4854-b7bd-368945e25f2e"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItemebd1b413-4c26-4c47-876d-9d7166eb7d8d" type="clause"/>—Integral Features</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:margin-note><lnci:cite><lnci:content>Capital Allowances Act 2001, s 33A</lnci:content></lnci:cite></lnb-prec:margin-note>Integral features are a special category of plant and machinery. They are defined by statute and include electrical systems, cold water systems, space and water heating systems, air conditioning systems, and lifts. Integral features represent an exception to the general rule that the definition of plant comes from case law. Statute specifically provides that integral features always qualify as plant (although they attract allowances at a lower rate). Capital allowances

In clause xref the following definitions apply:

Clause —Capital allowances

It is important on any sale of property to consider the position in relation to capital allowances. In order to qualify for plant and machinery allowances, expenditure must be:

  • capital

  • on plant and machinery, and

  • wholly or partly for the purposes of a qualifying activity

In addition, the person incurring the expenditure must own the plant and machinery as a result of that expenditure. See: Capital allowances—overview for further information on the qualification criteria.

Properties often have substantial plant and machinery. This may be:

  • fixtures, and/or

  • integral features

For information on the practicalities of capital allowance-related warranties and pre-contract enquiries on a property transfer, see Practice Note: Plant and machinery allowances on property acquisitions and disposals (including pre-contract enquiries).

The drafting in this clause is for use where the Seller has claimed allowances and the parties will enter into a section 198 election on Completion. For alternative drafting clauses where the Seller:

  • has claimed allowances and the parties will apply to the First-tier Tax Tribunal for a just and reasonable allocation of allowances; or

  • has claimed allowances but the information is not available on completion to enable a section 198 election to be entered into at completion; or

  • has not claimed capital allowances, and was not entitled to do so; or

  • was entitled to claim capital allowances but has not done so

see the drafting alternatives and notes in Precedent: Capital allowances clauses—property sale contract.

The purpose of a section 198 election is to determine, for capital allowances purposes, the amount of the price for the Property that should be attributed to fixtures on which the Seller has claimed allowances.

Depending on the circumstances, it may be necessary to use more than one variation of the capital gains clauses in this Precedent and also in Capital allowances clauses—property sale contract. For example, the Property may contain fixtures on which the Seller has claimed allowances, but also fixtures on which the Seller was not entitled to claim allowances, such as cold water or electrical systems acquired before April 2008. In this situation it may be appropriate to use both the drafting in this contract as well as option 4 in Capital allowances clauses—property sale contract, with modifications to make clear which clause applies to which category of fixture.

For more information see Practice Notes: Plant and machinery allowances—fixtures and Section 198 and 199 elections on transactions involving real estate property.

CAA 2001

Capital Allowances Act 2001;

Election

an election in respect of the Fixtures under section 198 of CAA 2001 in the form annexed to this Agreement as xref;

Clause —Election

For details of elections in real estate transactions, see Practice Note: Section 198 and 199 elections on transactions involving real estate property.

Fixtures

all plant and machinery which is installed or otherwise fixed in or to the Property so as to become (in law) part of the Property;

Clause —Fixtures

Fixtures are plant or machinery that is installed or fixed so that they become, in law, part of a building or land. Examples include boilers, alarm systems and fitted kitchen units. There are special rules to determine whether a taxpayer is eligible to claim allowances for expenditure on a fixture. In order to claim allowances, the taxpayer must have an interest in the land or building of which the fixture is part. Further rules determine who may claim allowances where more than one person might have a claim, for instance where a person constructs a building, installs fixtures, then leases the building to another person for a capital sum that includes a payment for those fixtures. For new fixtures, the capital allowances claim is based on the actual expenditure. For more information see Practice Note: Plant and machinery allowances—fixtures.

Integral Features

those Fixtures that are integral features for the purposes of section 33(A) of CAA 2001;

Clause —Integral Features

Capital Allowances Act 2001, s 33AIntegral features are a special category of plant and machinery. They are defined by statute and include electrical systems, cold water systems, space and water heating systems, air conditioning systems, and lifts. Integral features represent an exception to the general rule that the definition of plant comes from case law. Statute specifically provides that integral features always qualify as plant (although they attract allowances at a lower rate). For more information, see Practice Note: Plant and machinery allowances—integral features.

Non-integral Features

those Fixtures that are not Integral Features;

Prior Right

has the meaning of ‘prior right’ for the purposes of section 181(2) of CAA 2001.

On Completion the Seller and the Buyer shall make the Election and shall each, within insert number working days of Completion, deliver an executed original Election to their respective tax inspector at HMRC.

The amount to be fixed in respect of the Integral Features shall be £insert amount.

Clause —Integral and Non-integral Features

Dividing the fixtures into integral and non-integral features is the absolute minimum HMRC will accept. Depending on which fixtures exist in the Property, it may be necessary to subdivide them further and provide more details, such as 'electrical systems' or 'cold water systems'. In this case it may be better to delete clauses xref and xref rely on a more detailed breakdown in the proforma election in xref. See Precedent: Election—capital allowances apportionment on sale of land—CAA 2001, s 198.

The amount to be fixed in respect of the Non-integral Features shall be insert amount.

Each of the Buyer and the Seller shall:

provide all necessary information to each other and take all reasonable steps required to validly make the Election;

submit a copy of the Election to HMRC with their tax return for the first period affected by the Election;

take all reasonable steps to ensure that the amounts fixed by the Election are accepted by HMRC; and

reflect the amounts fixed by the Election in their respective tax computations and returns.

The Seller warrants that no person has a Prior Right in relation to any of the Fixtures.

The Seller warrants that the total and individual figures in the Election are no greater than the amounts incurred by it in accordance with CAA 2001 for the provision of the Fixtures.

Announcements

No announcement or other public disclosure concerning this Agreement or any of the matters contained in it shall be made by, or on behalf of, a party without the prior written consent of the other party such consent not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed, except as required by law, any court, any governmental, regulatory or supervisory authority (including, without limitation, any securities exchange) or any other authority of competent jurisdiction.

Clause —Announcements

This is a short form announcements provision. For a longer form clause see: Announcements clause.

This clause is drafted on the basis that:

  • it binds all of the parties to the contract

  • the general prohibition on announcements and other public disclosures relates to the existence of the contract itself and any of the matters contained in it

  • the parties will remain binding for the duration of the contract (if the clause is intended to survive termination of the contract, this may be stated in the clause itself or elsewhere in the contract, eg in the termination or survival clause)

  • an announcement or other public disclosure may be made with the prior written consent of the other party, with no express process being set out to obtain such consent, although it must not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed, and

  • an announcement or other public disclosure may be made as required by law, a court or any other authority, without any prior written consent from the other party or any consultation with them being required.

    The announcements clause normally forms part of the main contract relating to a transaction or arrangement and, as such, will take effect on the signing of the contract. Prior to signing, any announcement relating to the proposed transaction or arrangement will normally be restricted by the terms of a confidentiality agreement entered into between the parties. The terms of such a confidentiality agreement should be considered in drafting an announcements clause; it would be usual for the announcements clause (along with any confidentiality clause) to replace this initial confidentiality agreement.

    It is necessary to consider an announcements clause in the contract in conjunction with any confidentiality clause, to ensure that the two work effectively together.

Governing law

This Agreement and any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, it, its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims) shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of England and Wales.

Clause —Governing law

This governing law clause provides that the agreement and certain disputes and claims shall governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of England and Wales, although a reference to another substantive law may be inserted instead.

The wording as to the types of dispute and claim to be covered is deliberately wide in its reference to any ‘dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, it, its subject matter or formation’ and this wording can been made narrower if that is preferred. However, consideration should then be given as to the law that will govern any such disputes or claims that do not fall within the scope of the clause.

Regulation (EC) 864/2007The words ‘[(including non-contractual disputes or claims)]’ may be included for the purpose of Rome II, which sets out the rules used to determine the governing law for non-contractual claims. However, parties pursuing a commercial activity can specify the governing law that will apply to their non-contractual obligations at any time before an event giving rise to damage occurs, save that such governing law cannot prevent the application of:

  • any laws of the country in which all of the elements relevant to the situation are located when the event occurs (if it is not the country whose law has been chosen), if those laws cannot be derogated from by agreement, and

  • European Community law that cannot be derogated from by agreement, if all of the elements relevant to the situation are located in one or more EU member states when the event occurs and the law that has been chosen is not that of an EU member state

In the absence of the phrase ‘[(including non-contractual disputes or claims)]’ the wording of this clause may be wide enough in its scope to catch non-contractual claims relating to the agreement, its subject matter or formation. However, these words are a helpful addition to provide certainty to the parties.

If the intention of the parties is to restrict the governing law clause only to contractual claims, the wording of the clause should be amended to refer only to disputes or claims arising under the agreement, eg:

‘This agreement and any dispute or claim arising under it shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of [England and Wales/insert details of alternative governing law].’

clause: <lnb-prec:clause id="ukContentItem1490085952-34828125"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Jurisdiction</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>The parties irrevocably agree that the courts of England and Wales shall have exclusive jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, this <lnb-prec:term class="document-class">Agreement</lnb-prec:term>, its subject matter or formation <lnb-prec:field opt-key="opt-N65640">(including non-contractual disputes or claims)</lnb-prec:field>.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:inclusion id="ukContentItem6a4733a3-5990-4eba-b100-19fe125ff259"><lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:text>Clause <lnb-prec:xref id-ref="ukContentItem1490085952-34828125" type="clause"/>—Jurisdiction</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:title><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>This clause provides that the courts of England and Wales shall have jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, the agreement. </lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text>The wording as to the types of dispute and claim to be covered is deliberately wide in its reference to any ‘dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, it, its subject matter or formation’ and this wording can been made narrower if that is preferred. However, consideration should then be given as to the courts that will have jurisdiction to settle any such disputes or claims, which do not fall within the scope of the clause.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:margin-note><lnci:cite><lnci:content>Fiona Trust v Privalov and others [2007] All ER (D) 233 (Oct) </lnci:content></lnci:cite></lnb-prec:margin-note><lnb-prec:margin-note><lnci:cite><lnci:content>UBS AG v HSH Nordbank AG [2009] EWCA Civ 585, para 82</lnci:content></lnci:cite></lnb-prec:margin-note>The inclusion of the wording 'arise out of, or in connection with' and similar terms in a jurisdiction clause used to cause difficulties as to exactly what type of disputes were brought within its scope. The House of Lords has, in an arbitration case, upheld a wide interpretation of these words. This was on the assumption that the parties, as rational businessmen, were likely to have intended <lnb-prec:em class="it">any</lnb-prec:em> dispute arising out of their relationship to be decided by the tribunal referred to in the relevant clause. The wording was held to be so wide as to cover claims arising before inception of the relevant agreement, such as misrepresentation. This wide interpretation has subsequently been followed in a number of litigation cases.</lnb-prec:text></lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:block><lnb-prec:text><lnb-prec:margin-note><lnci:cite><lnci:content>Fiona Trust v Privalov and others [2007] All ER (D) 233 (Oct)</lnci:content></lnci:cite></lnb-prec:margin-note>The words ‘[(including non-contractual disputes or claims)]’ may be included if the same wording is included in the agreement’s governing law clause for the purpose of Rome II. Jurisdiction

The parties irrevocably agree that the courts of England and Wales shall have exclusive jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, this Agreement, its subject matter or formation (including non-contractual disputes or claims).

Clause —Jurisdiction

This clause provides that the courts of England and Wales shall have jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, the agreement.

The wording as to the types of dispute and claim to be covered is deliberately wide in its reference to any ‘dispute or claim arising out of, or in connection with, it, its subject matter or formation’ and this wording can been made narrower if that is preferred. However, consideration should then be given as to the courts that will have jurisdiction to settle any such disputes or claims, which do not fall within the scope of the clause.

Fiona Trust v Privalov and others [2007] All ER (D) 233 (Oct) UBS AG v HSH Nordbank AG [2009] EWCA Civ 585, para 82The inclusion of the wording 'arise out of, or in connection with' and similar terms in a jurisdiction clause used to cause difficulties as to exactly what type of disputes were brought within its scope. The House of Lords has, in an arbitration case, upheld a wide interpretation of these words. This was on the assumption that the parties, as rational businessmen, were likely to have intended any dispute arising out of their relationship to be decided by the tribunal referred to in the relevant clause. The wording was held to be so wide as to cover claims arising before inception of the relevant agreement, such as misrepresentation. This wide interpretation has subsequently been followed in a number of litigation cases.

Fiona Trust v Privalov and others [2007] All ER (D) 233 (Oct)The words ‘[(including non-contractual disputes or claims)]’ may be included if the same wording is included in the agreement’s governing law clause for the purpose of Rome II. However, following the decision in the Fiona Trust case, such wording is not strictly necessary.
